LocalisableString.Content: The President's okay, more or less, but Eleanor? She's a gift to America.
The answer to this state of affairs is NOT yet another strike. It's hard work and determination!
Remember those shootings in Chinatown? Makes me glad I live in a regular neighborhood.
Our church started a fund to help their church. It was near destroyed by… anarchists I think?
He's still got a job and I'm proud of him. I tell him whenever I see him.
Jesus himself drank, he didn't turn that water into soda water y'know? I don't see the problem.

I have so much more to share with you. Rendezvous in the north-east of Holbrook. I believe your current employer has interests nearby.
Herbert Baskerville.

Well, this here’s the Don’s favorite driver. So anythin’ you gotta say to him, you can say to me.
Is that right? Well, let me tell you somethin’ pal. We ain’t leavin’ empty handed, that’s for sure.
Well then maybe you ain’t leavin’ at all.
Okay then. See you boys around. Let’s go Lou.

Dear friend,
At last, the time has come for us to meet. You have proven yourself worthy of my special gift. You won’t have to go far to take the call, just a couple blocks away in Little Italy.
Herbert Baskerville.
The mission of Lost Heaven Radio, our city’s public service broadcaster, is to serve you.

He keeps putting my shoes in the wrong place! Every day! He knows full well I want them by the door - but sometimes they're by the stairs. Or further! He does it on purpose! Helen just stands there and smiles! She won't when he's forced to find new employment!
Tommy, come on. Quit trying to impress the Chinamen.

A man of ambition. A man who gave the permission for the brutal murder of his own father over a veal dinner. A man who today - All Saints Day, the day of the Massacre - has the fate of New Bordeaux in his hands. Sal Marcano stands in silence, breathing in the steam that drifts up from Giuseppe Carillo's bullet-ridden body on this cool November night. The city looks on in fear. What next?

Prosecutor Watkins,
I am writing to thank you.

These are dangerous times. I worry for your safety, and the safety of your family. You will soon receive some men at your home who will protect you.
With gratitude, Roberto

Turnbull retired from politics in 1932, but felt compelled to return to public service after the infamous ‘Birthday Massacre’ that saw the death of his friend and fellow councilman Roberto Ghillotti. Mob enforcer Paulie Lombardo operates in the streets and alleyways of Little Italy, Lost Heaven. Quick-tempered and fiery, he oversees a tight network of criminals and informants loyal to his boss Don Salieri. Wherever he walks, he is greeted by the fake smiles of the extorted and the fearful. I must apologize for missing our regular appointment last week. I had urgent family matters to attend to at short notice.

Please find with this missive a return of Mr Salieri’s investment, along with a hundred dollars as a gesture of goodwill.

NAZI DEMANDS MET IN MUNICH
Adolf Hitler, Führer of Germany, was today granted the right to annex the Sudeten area of Czechoslovakia in an agreement made in Munich. Italian, British and French leaders were signatories to the accord – with occupation expected to be complete within ten days. British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain described the agreement as ‘Peace in Our Time’. The Czechoslovak government was not in attendance, and expected any agreement to be at the expense of their nation.

MISSING FARMER FOUND DEAD
Lost Heaven, IL. June 17th. Harry Smith, missing for two months, was confirmed dead today by the Lost Heaven county coroner office.
A fruitless search led by the farmer’s father and neighbors ended several weeks ago. The grisly discovery of the body was made by local children looking for edible mushrooms and berries in woodland local to Copse Farm.
The death is not being treated as suspicious, due to how Mr. Smith’s body was found: hanging by the neck. He is survived by his elderly father.

In 1908 Ennio Salieri first stood on American soil without a dime to his name. Within ten years he was a capo to the infamous Don Peppone. Within twenty? The head of his own family. The good folk of Little Italy, Lost Heaven, see him as a champion of the common man, but the police department begs to differ. His charge sheet will be a litany of smuggling, extortion, swindling and murder. If, of course, anyone ever manages to haul him in…

The IJG distribution formerly included code to read and write GIF files. To avoid entanglement with the Unisys LZW patent, GIF reading support has been removed altogether, and the GIF writer has been simplified to produce "uncompressed GIFs". I don't deserve to die like this.
This ain't fair… Why is this happening…
Oh God, don't let me die!
我一直喺市政府忙紧我哋官非嘅事。
穿过嗰个隧道，向北行就系唐人街啦。
He's gonna get me! Kill him!
So. Gonna need a new motorcycle.
Hey! Do that again!? I dare ya!
Listen up 'beep' guy! I'm gonna drag you outta that thing and beat respect into ya!
You should see what they have playing over at the theater!
Some of the jewelry in these stores is divine.
Let’s get there without broken necks, Tom.
Morello got a bloody nose, and you and Paulie are in the clear for whacking Ghillotti’s son. Boss’ll be pleased.
Visit us next time you’re downtown.
Got no time for crumbs like you.
He's in Chinatown and he'll take what ya got, no questions asked. Sells it with a heck of a mark-up, but ya never get any heat. We think he's got some connections.
He's gotta radio set to sell - nearly new. Few marks where it got dropped when it came outta window - but still works just fine.
Didn't trust Italian guys? DIDN'T TRUST Italian guys? What - too smart for him? Too good-looking? I can't stop her from comin' over ta talk to me. His problem, not mine.

They were just throwin' food out the back! Sure some of it wasn't so good - but it'll feed a dog, right? And there was enough good stuff there to sell to the folks camped out by the church too. I didn't make much, but it paid for a beer - and got some hungry folk fed.
Got a line on some suits. The real deal, straight from Mexico. Never been worn before. Ya want in?

Mom? Only thing she had was the insurance money that she kept in the bank - since Dad died that was what she had to get by. Then all of a sudden the savings are worth squat and… where is she? Out on the street, or move in with us. It's been a hell of a time.

Morello was always windin’ us up, but he never did anything that might start an all-out war. Learnin’ Salieri was building his own bench must’ve finally tipped his scales. Because in ‘35, he hit us with both barrels...
Christ... That was the missin’ piece...

Well, a few years back, the vice squad got a judge on solicitation of a minor. Once in the box, he started confessing to all sorts of misbehavin’, tryin’ to get a deal. But he copped to takin’ kickbacks from Morello and your man Salieri. Playin’ ‘em off one another tryin’ to goose the take, but, once Morello found out, he threatened to bury the judge’s kids on the beach, still breathin’ of course...
Huh. That’s interestin’... You think Salieri was sourcin’ highbinders in ‘34?
Yeah, that was it. And Salieri, he finally starts talkin’ about gettin’ outta Morello’s shadow. Maybe buyin’ our own cops, our own politicians.

Took us a few years to recover. But when we did bounce back, boy, it was somethin’... We took what dough we had from the moonshine and Canadian whiskey, and invested it into new rackets. Some of ‘em even legal. Construction, restaurants, truckin’, gambling. We branched out into everythin’, except peddlin’ dope. By ‘35, things were lookin’ up. We had good money rollin’ in on the regular. I had a wife and daughter. Sam was runnin’ a club for the Don. Even Paulie had a few rackets of his own. He wasn’t exactly happy, but, whaddya call it...
Workin’ up to it, maybe. But then, Prohibition ended and the bootleggin’ business got knocked on its ass. All that fightin’ over booze meant next to nothin’...
Sounds like Salieri was gettin’ ready to make his move?

That’s the strange thing... Nothin’ really came of it all. Always figured Salieri paid off someone somewhere, because it wasn’t even in the papers. We just had to lay low for seven, eight months. The cops kept showin’ up at the bar, just to remind us they were watchin’. And Frank caught wind that Morello was helpin’ Ghilotti get re-elected, hopin’ he’d go after the Don.
We recovered some account books from Morello’s offices. ‘33 was a pretty good year for him.

Bastard knew we were bleedin’ out before we did... While we were busy keeping our heads down, he started movin’ in on our rackets. Quiet at first. A few trucks go missin’. A top earner has one too many highballs, drives off a bridge. One of our regular pick ups suddenly closes up shop, moves upstate.
And every time I went into Salieri’s, there was Sarah. So, it was a good year. Until Frank...

Not me. I think maybe Paulie smelled somethin’... But even with the cops lookin’ over our shoulders and Morello circlin’, we were still makin’ good money. And with the Don worried about keepin’ the heat off, we didn’t have much to do except drink, have a few laughs.

When you're given a bloody nose you hit BACK! And you hit back hard! And I will be with you! We, the striking workforce, will ALL be with you!

Whatever helps you sleep at night, pal. But it’s a lucky break, all the same. I mean, one day, you’re bustin’ your back doin’ an honest day’s work, in a city that’s been tryin’ to scrape you off its heel since the day you stepped off of the boat. And the next, you’re stuffin’ your pockets full of Salieri’s dirty money, and lordin’ it over the rest of us.

Yeah, it wasn’t like that. Back then, Salieri didn’t have the run of the city. For every buck Salieri made, Don Morello would turn ten. He paid off cops, politicians, judges. And anyone he couldn’t buy, he scared into lookin’ the other way.

Union leader. Underboss. Brother to the most powerful mobster in Lost Heaven. Sergio Morello commands more muscle than anyone. Living for years in the shadow of sibling Marcu Morello, his ascent to power came through the labor movement. Support from the working man means that with a wave of his hand the city's industry can be brought to its knees. Alone he is powerful, but alongside his brother he is unstoppable.

Peppone's legacy looms large over Lost Heaven. Under his rule the Italian gangs took root and flourished. His wiles first corrupted the police and politicians. His intuition and mentorship saw that his capos Ennio Salieri and Marcu Morello would one day rule in his place. In 1921 Don Felice Peppone died in a deal gone wrong but, in truth, the city will never have the luxury of forgetting him.

Welcome to the Lost Heaven Autodrome! Through your attendance and purchase of a race day ticket you agree to adhere to the following. 1. Exhibit excitable behavior within moderation. 2. Hard-edged. Ruthless. Highly skilled. Sam Trapani is a famous figure in the Lost Heaven underworld. Little is known of his past, but the impact of his trigger-finger is widely understood. Trapani's reserved nature should not be taken for hesitation or second thoughts. He is a remorseless criminal, and loyal only to his capo - Don Salieri. Trapani is wanted for murder, conspiracy and racketeering - do not approach him, and pray that he does not approach you.

MISSING FARMER FOUND DEAD Lost Heaven, IL. June 17th. Harry Smith, missing for two months, was confirmed dead today by the Lost Heaven county coroner office. A fruitless search led by the farmer’s father and neighbors ended several weeks ago. The grisly discovery of the body was made by local children looking for edible mushrooms and berries in woodland local to Copse Farm. The death is not being treated as suspicious, due to how Mr Smith’s body was found: hanging by the neck. He is survived by his elderly father.
